Very few mythological or literary swords were inherently magical or powerful beyond enhanced physical qualities (such as never rusting, breaking, or needing to be sharpened, or some amount of glowing). Some rarer magical — but not conventionally “powerful” — traits in mythological weapons include rejecting or somehow attacking an unworthy wielder and minorly enhancing the fighting ability of their users by having perfect aim or something of the sort. Usually, the great magical feats accomplished with swords are actually due to the abilities of their wielders, with the sword channeling power somewhat like a wand or staff rather than being the actual source of the magic. Other times, mythological swords were seen as a symbol of power (and not inherently powerful, though the two are frequently confused) as is the case with Excalibur. There are a few — emphasis on few — mythical weapons that I know of that were meaningfully powerful beyond use as a physical weapon, but most are not swords or even applicable to swords. I think they tend to be more common in Norse and Irish mythologies, but I’m no expert. There is a staff or something similar called Kaladanda in Hindu tradition that kills whoever it strikes. The club of Dagda also magically brought death, but also could be used to bring people back to life.Cupid’s arrows made the target fall in love.Several weapons would magically return to their owners once used, such as Lugh’s spear, certain arrows in Hindu tradition, and Thor’s hammer Mjolnir.Dainsleif was a sword that was cursed (so, not sure if that’s the sword’s power or not) that couldn’t be sheathed until it was used to kill somebody.
